I cleared my cookies and lost all of my filters, oops.
Anyway here are my filters that I use for /tttt/. The filters themselves will be left unquoted so you can easily copy them.

/^>/
>This is my universal filter that prunes out threads that begin with a quote.There's no good 4chan threads that begin with a quote, it's either shitposting, trolling, bait, astroturfing, raiding or all of the above.
/tran(n|s[\sgwi]{1,})./
>This one filters out "tranny", "trans", "transwoman", "transgender", "transgirl", "transition" and their derivatives while leaving "translation" intact. Since I'm even less interested reading about trannies on other boards, it's also a universal filter.
/troon*|trann*/
>To catch "troon" and derivatives.
agp*|hrt|ffs|mtf*|*siss*
>Self-explanatory. As a bonus it fitlers out "oh no, X-sissies, what will we do?"
*brain*|repress*|pass*|repper*|chase*|repg*
>Also self-explanatory. I could fit this into one big filter, but I prefer dividing them up into manageable chunks if I want to add something without the risk of making other filters not work.
/.hon[^e]./
>Filters out "shoulderhon", "hon", "hons", "honfidence" etc. but doesn't touch "honest".
*estro*|progest*|hormon*|inject*
dysphor*
>Again, self-explanatory.
"kino pairing"
>For that one obese spammer.
/(be|become|is) a[\w\s]{1,}(woman|girl)/
>Filters out all known to me combinations of "be a woman".
/(a|A)(m|M|f|F|g|G)(A|a)(B|b)*/
>Prunes out AMAB/AFAB talk and various capitalisations of it.
/(boy|man|girl)mo(d|dd)/
>All babble about Xmodders out.
virgin chad
>Another universal filter.
*mboy*|*pill*
>Clears out the catalogue of all Xpillers and femboy (cryptotranny) shit. As a bonus it gets rid of annoying tomboyhets in /a/djacent boards.

Also for the easy trollable boards like /tg/ it's prudent to include this filter that blocks lazy baitposts which end in question marks. If it's a question followed by something else, it has a chance of not being a retarded so it leaves it.
/\?$/

Maybe? But not right away and not constantly like you. My earliest "issues" probably go back to when I was 5 or 6, when I rebelled against swimming without a shirt on (despite being skinny). See that's the crucial part that I'm missing. I didn't grow up wishing to be a woman (aside from feeling more comfortable in women's locker rooms when I was young). It only started hitting me *recently*... after I allowed myself to wonder what it would be like to be a woman.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29100021
Women are at an increased risk of breast cancer because they're using exogenous estrogen past the point which their biology determined it was time to shut down natural production. The same goes for men who do TRT when they see an age-related decline in testosterone production: exogenous testosterone use increases the risk of prostate cancer as high T (and DHT) levels are a risk factor for prostate cancer. The longer you stay at elevated levels, the greater your risk is. The same is true for women regarding estrogen and breast cancer.

Detransitioners likely see more impact from HRT "the second time around" because taking hormones and drugs which are actively destroying your HPTA function, therefor suppressing your test production for probably months upon months after cessation of treatment (depending on the length, dose, and substances used in said treatment) will give estrogen a much smaller proverbial hill to climb to become the dominant hormone over testosterone. You don't just "bounce back in a few weeks" after taking estrogen for 6+months and having T levels 1/10th of a healthy male, if that. I've yet to hear of any evidence to suggest that exogenous estrogen administration in males DOESN'T shut down the HPTA - and considering that you can use "monotherapy" doses of estrogen to nuke T, you might as well treat HRT as if it has the potential to cause HPTA disruption and hypogonadism similar if not equal to the level of male AAS users. That being: the longer the time on exogenous hormones + the higher the dose of the compound = the larger the damage (likely permanent) to the HPTA. Lower test levels = more effective administration of estrogen HRT treatment as there is less "competition" to be the dominant hormone.

Less T to compete with upon administration of hormones, a weaker HPTA to nuke to ensure the exogenous hormones stay dominant, and a "familiarity" with the E dominant physiology is a more likely explanation than "developing receptors".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29101539
if you look at the infographic in the op, there's some guidelines for dosing early in transition. A lot of people recommend low doses for the first ~1 year to better approximate normal female puberty. Some people think that this also results in better breast growth. But if you start at low doses you'll probably need antiandrogens, as your estrogen levels won't be high enough to fully suppress testosterone.
If you have naturally low T it might work, but you'd need blood tests to make sure. It's not worth it to just hope that your levels are good.
Alternatively, you could start at a monotherapy dose, something like 5mg EV every 5 days. This should be enough to suppress testosterone without an antiandrogen, but again you'd want to get blood tests to make sure your levels are good. Some people do this and still get good results, but usually people start on lower doses.

>PEP has antigonadotropic effects due to its estrogenic activity.[36] It has been found to suppress testosterone levels in men by 55%, 75%, and 85% at intramuscular dosages of 80, 160, and 240 mg every 4 weeks, respectively.[46] A single intramuscular injection of 320 mg PEP in men has been found to suppress testosterone levels to within the castrate range (< 50 ng/dL) within 3 weeks.[7] This was associated with circulating estradiol levels of just over 200 pg/mL.[35] The suppression of testosterone levels that can be achieved with PEP is equal to that with orchiectomy.[48] However, to achieve such concentrations of testosterone, which are about 15 ng/dL on average, higher concentrations of estradiol of around 500 pg/mL were necessary.[35][48][49] This was associated with a dosage of intramuscular 320 mg PEP every four weeks and occurred by 90 days of treatment.[35] However, 240 mg PEP every four weeks has also been reported to eventually suppress testosterone levels in the castrate range.[50][51]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29103164
Both are used as treatments for breast cancer. Raloxifene reduces risk of non-invasive breast cancer by about 38 percent compared to tamoxifen reducing risk for this type of cancer by about 50 percent. So raloxifene is about 78 percent as effective as tamoxifen in reducing the risk of noninvasive breast cancer over almost 7 years. This suggests that tamoxifen may be more effective.but raloxifene has fewer harmful side effects than tamoxifen and may be a better choice for some women. Especially because you would busing it to prevent breast growth, not treat cancer, I'd opine that the risk/benefit calculation favors ralox over tamox. Tamox is a riskier option and more appropriate in treating serious diseases like breast cancer than cosmetic concerns like gynecomastia. However, ralox still increases risk of VTE/serious blood clots, as do estradiol and progesterone. So take the minimum dose of each medication necessary and avoid smoking. In STAR, women in the raloxifene group had 28 percent fewer deep-vein thromboses (blood clots in a major vein) and 20 percent fewer pulmonary embolisms (blood clots in the lung) than women on tamoxifen: 118 of 9,736 women in the tamoxifen group had a deep-vein thrombosis compared to 86 of 9,754 women in the raloxifene group.

posts.name: Salazar
posts.com:
>>29101540
AAS definitely are more suppressive than estrogens since most people on estradiol are able to bounce back their HPGA on their own. With AASz you generally need PCT cycles if you want to return to baseline (if you even do make a full recovery), as opposed to waiting months or a lifetime waiting for natural recovery (many times this results in recovery to sub baseline test levels). Unfortunately there isn't really a metric geared towards gonadotropin suppression besides time which itself is abstract since it isn't studied much long term. Another thing to note is I don't think it's a good idea to say you're "damaging" your HPGA, you're just downregulating it, although you are correct that intensity and time in exogenous hormones has greater effects.

I find steroids and the HPG axis to be super cool, I wanted to write a paper on possibly using androgenic compounds (counterintuitive but controllable) with high anabolic:androgenic ratios in transfeminine HRT as a method of getting bootleg GNRHs. Fortunately, it seems not as difficult to access GNRHs to where you'd have to consider such an option, although the prospects are alluring considering 19-nor androgens are so suppressive for extended periods of time compared to others.

>>29100201
Finasterids is directly inferior to dutasteride as it blocks more DHT. Also, 5AR inhibitors will not restore your hairline, just prevent further balding. This is why people take topical vasodilators like minoxidil to promote blood flow to hair follicles; research has shown its extra effective when combined with derma rolling too (although derma pens/stamps which have an up and down motion are better for the skin).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29118477
https://www.med24.se/sjukskoeterskeartiklar/kanyler/bd-micro-fine-plus-0-3-ml-u-100-100-st
These ones. They're graduated in insulin units (U), but it's easy to convert. 1U = 0.01ml. So in your case you'd draw air to the 5U line, insert into the vial, press out the air, draw the E up to the 5U marker, put the vial back, stick the needle into your belly one fist away from your belly button, and inject (slowly). Leave it in a few seconds after you're done injecting, and then gently pull it out.
Get yourself a plastic bin for the used needles, you can empty it at a hospital or pharmacy. Nobody's going to ask but if they do just say they're insulin needles, because they literally are.

Yep.
T builds muscle, and your T is basically completely unharmed. The bica will continue suppressing it, though weaker and weaker, until it's completely eliminated. IIRC the half life is 6 days, so every 6 days you'll have half as much bica in your blood. After a week or two its effects should be negligible.
While the bica is active you'll build muscle at a female rate, ie slowly, but you won't lose what you already have. Just wait it out, adding T is pointless.

Why would you go to an endo unless you had to? It’s way more expensive and you’re probably not getting any “expertise.” Just use a telehealth provider like plume or folx if you live in a state where you can, or go to PP if you don’t.

PP they will ask many questions that are easy to answer. You will talk to doc and they will prescribe you a semi-hondose for 3 months to make sure you’re actually wanting to do hrt. Usually 2mg sublingual tablets per day (1mg x2) and 100mg spiro per day (50mg x2). At 3mo they ask if you want to step up your dose. You say yes if you do. Etc etc. just do your research and don’t do dumb stuff if they tell you to do dumb stuff (there’s not a lot of continuing education required so most of them don’t know that you split your doses evenly throughout the day, dumb shit like that.) They will generally do whatever you ask them to within reason.

posts.com:
Hands-on guardian angels Edition
previous: >>29101662

Goal of the thread: Treat yourself to something nice, be it a meal, a hot bath, or something else you'd enjoy doing.
Daily goals can be repeated. Remember to keep score, it can only go up!

>What is this thread for?
Getting better is hard, and sucks. A lot. It does not get easier doing it alone.
Share resources and experiences with combating depression, anxiety, personal issues, achieving or maintaining a healthy weight, etc.
>Why is this thread /lgbt/?
Struggles with mental and physical health are an indisputable part of /lgbt/ life, be it from dysphoria, social pressure, heartbreak, or just unfortunate lifestyle choices.
>Notes to consider:
Please be civil. Shame is your greatest enemy in fighting urges of self abuse (be it sh, drugs, or just self deprecation). Relapsing into bad and unhealthy habits is to be expected, the goal is to increase the average amount of time it takes between relapses. Any improvement is a victory no matter how small. Your worth and right to get better are non-negotiable. And most importantly:
WE ARE NOT THERAPISTS, WE DON'T REPLACE MEDICATION
>Note on advice
Generic advice won't necessarily help you in particular, but for those it does it is an essential foundation to build future progress on, not a miracle cure. Do not underestimate the effects subtle changes to your lifestyle can have. Try first, keep us posted on your progress, build from there.

We are *always* short on self help resources, so if anything was useful to you, let us know!
Since the OP is getting too long I moved all resources into their own post, see below!

resources:
Exercise, diet, weight loss/gain: >>>/fit/17018018 (sticky)
Assorted self help resources (anxiety, depression, sleep issues, ED, and more) https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself
NIMH brochures on mental health topics (Depression, BPD, ADHD, etc): https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/publications
ED: https://www.eatingdisorderhope.com/treatment-for-eating-disorders

General advice from Anons: https://0x0.st/o7c7.txt (Updated!)

Get started with weight loss (courtesy of /fit/fat/):
>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with LoseIt, Cronometer or Waistline (Open Source)

A few short overview videos (need review by other anons):
Common Sources of Misery: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LO1mTELoj6o

A few immediate suggestions are: dispose of the heroin, ideally in a way that destroys it immediately so that it is not a danger to yourself or others.

>Bulimia is difficult, and we have resources above for ED which I would love you to take a look at and tell me if they are of use to you.
sorry its quite late and i just took my meds which make me unable to think straight. i had a quick look through some of the worksheets they offer and the one on 'Tackling Avoided Foods' is great and something i did in my head a lot. challenging your own fears and thoughts around certain foods is liberating. that goes for intuitive eating too. getting used to not excessively controlling your intake, proving to yourself empirically via measurements and observing your emotional reaction to such.
anotehr thing they speak of, and something i found beneficial, is eating to fuel your body as a machine. i couldnt concentrate and didnt realize how much of my world was occupied by my ed. i started out eating to think properly, it was nice to be free of the brain fog.
i never found cost to be a motivator, but it was an exhausting experience, so thats a good motivator, to be free of that. and to be able to enjoy outings with friends and family.
distractions are an amazing tool that can help you keep the thoughts at bay but that comes into play later once youre no longer consumed by thoughts around eating/cooking/planning meals, which comes into regulation once youve worked yourself into intuitive eating.
ive been free of bulimia for a whole year now, but i relapse a few times here and there, but never to the extent i did in the past. i used to binge purge 7+ times a day, spending £50+ daily, and was told i needed inpatient and couldnt be helped, and was then cast into the void again lmao.
the resources on there around diet etc are good too, throwing yourself into fitness and nutrition is a good escape avenue, as it still gives that aspect of control over your physique and intake, but for the better. but it can quickly spiral into orthorexia lol.
2/2

>what makes you think that.
im at a disadvantage compared to the rest of society considering my mental illnesses. the system is setup in such a way that if you trip and fall, youre seen as a loss and milked for every penny you have until you an hero. i came from a place where i was fortunate enough to have good income and savings. i lost everything and more in due time, it hurts the most to look back and see everything youve lost. name it, ive lost it. my transition, my car, my savings, my physical health (from drug addiction), my cognitive functioning, etc etc
i recognize that it will take a significant amount of time and effort from now (been at it for nearly 5 years now) to have even a fraction of what i had prior, at the expense of my own wellbeing. im not emotionally strong enough, everyone has their own tolerance level and breaking point.
>what drove you to it?
i was neck deep in my bulimia, id just started getting addicted to xanax and ketamine, applied for ffs with my savings at the time, forced myself to get clean for it. i was scheduled in for surgery. they asked if i had any prior hospitalizations, i consulted my bf and we both agreed its better to be honest. i was honest about hospitalization for previous suicide attempts. they then postponed my surgery until i could get a medical professional to say i was of sound mind. i went to my gender therapist, he didnt want to know. he told me to go ask his friend who was £450 a session whod need to see me for a year, with no guarantee of outcome. i consulted 5 further specialists (psychs and therapists galore), none would help me. id never felt so lonely or abandoned in my life.
>they must tell you why, certainly.
they have nothing within the nhs to offer me, nothing i havent tried before that didnt work. meds, therapies. its been widely recognized by all, including myself, that i need long term, consistent care with a therapist specialized in trauma i can build trust and rapport with.

I hope you are safer now, anon. I'm sorry you had to go through awful things. But yeah I think the source of your feelings is very clear.
I feel like the best way to overcome it is exposure. As in, you can address particular, specific fears by being exposed to them in a safe environment. Exposure therapy, essentially. You will need to experience observed reality contradicting your expectations. The biggest questionmark is the relapses you may experience. For example, suppose you made a fair bit of progress, and later you find a woman being exceptionally cuntish to you in a way that affirms your fears. You may sometimes feel like you are back at square one. You won't be, though. And you will find yourself less and less easily shaken as time passes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29136349
>How do people work most of the day only to go home and do whatever is necessary to be an acceptable member of society?
It's like giving a ball a push. Most of the effort gets expended at the start- after that things have their own momentum and get easier. Think of the last thing you did that was hard for you. Was the toughest part the middle, or the beginning? Do you give up on a shower halfway through?
It might also be useful to ask what you want and need. I don't know your situation, but could you get away with part-time or remote work? If your social anxiety is severe, it might be easier to take it piece by piece (a bearable amount of work here, a bearable amount of human contact there,) instead of jumping into an overwhelming amount all at once.
One final set of questions: Are there any things you feel passionate about, or find a lot of fun? It's easier to put yourself through something difficult if you have a reason at the end of the day (even if it's something silly like a shrimp tank or figurine collection or w/e). In my experience "improving myself" or "meeting x-y-z's expectations" haven't been enough. What motivates (or could motivate) you?

>>29122772
>What made you want to transition in the first place?
I hated body hair, acne, and most of all: hairloss. I tried fin and minox for years but they never stopped it. Only hrt did
I was attracted to men but I never had the guts to act on it because the idea of me being with another man as a man feels disgusting. I'd rather be a straight woman or straight man
I was also oblivious to the difference between men and women. I thought the difference was only physical. That might have been because I had no friends or partners, so I just didn't get how people work
Anyway, eventually my therapist pushed me to socially transition, so I met alot of trannies, and I became best friends one who feels like an actual woman (most of the ones I met felt like men)

We talked for months and shared our experiences, and I realized that I misunderstood what dysphoria meant.
She transitioned because she never learned how to be a man, so she had to act like one all the time to blend in. This constant act made her miserable and drove her to transition so she can just exist spontaneously. She also never hated being gay before transition
I never had to act at all, I just hated my male body. By socially transitioning I was trying to act like something I'm not and giving myself the same misery that drove her to transition. Basically, I was the opposite of a tranny
Final nail in the coffin was finding out I'm autistic. Apparently it was obvious to everyone but me. It's probably why I thought I could be a woman by just changing my body

Tldr: I thought dysphoria was hating being a man. Turns out I had a combo of body dysmorphia, autism, and internalized homophobia

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>29122332

Real men love being men. They aren't repressing trannies.

I'm not going to judge but like, i notice some themes here

>no one really loves themself right?
>i'll jusy settle for being a gay male
>i'll never act like a woman, i failed
>sure i'd want to be a girl if i could but i'll just settle for x. Don't want to keep indulging the mindless fetish of thinking i could be a girl.

This type of emotional inertia is i. My voew a hallmark of the way you think in your 20s, when age 30 feels like a death sentence and you often believe you've lost something along with your youth. You think that growing up means "giving up" on some aspect of identity and that you just settle down to get through the rest of your life in suspended animation.

But the thing is, life is a lot longer and more complicated than you realize. Once the things holding you down are removed, you'll be forced to confront your feelings again.

To be clear i mean thoughts like "i could never act like a woman" if you unpack that thought and the stereotypes that we use to define women and how restrictive they are you can start to see being a wpman as an act of defying norms rather than conforming to norms.

Anyway, life is long and these things take time to sort out. But as a 31 year old mtftmtf i would really warn people against the "i give up, i'll just be gay because its easier" mindset.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I detransitioned after living m2f for about 10 years.
>How long did it take?

About two years thinking about it and then about a month later got surgery to remove the breast implants. Then started dressing male again right away. Still got called she/her by people in public though a lot. Uncomfortable.

>Did regrowing the muscle hurt as much as losing it?

My body makes no T now due to earlier surgery and I decided not to take T. So I've not been able to gain any muscle despite trying. There are a lot of risks with T supplements and my doctors say I'm fine as I am but being weak now sucks.

>What did you do about the breast growth?

When I had the implants removed they removed any growth. Flat chest again but scars.

>Do you look the same now as before you started transitioning?

No years of female hormones softened all my features. I try to fit in by dressing as male as possible but still have an androgynous look unfortunately. Like an older David Bowie or something.

>And what was it like in general?
It was a hard decision but I'm glad I detransitioned. Life as mtf was constant stress and it never felt natural. I would urge others to not transition. In my case I think it was simply misdiagnosed ocd. I couldn't stop thinking that something was off with me and that obsession took ever my life and I made some terrible irreversible decisions because of it. It's just mental illness and transition does not cure it.

>>29126251
Do yourself a favour and see a therapist to see if you can figure out *why* you feel this way.

There are hugboxy therapists who'll be all "everyone should transition if they feel this way" and also anti-trans ones who'll just try and convince you not to do it. Avoid both of these types –find an open-minded therapist who'll help you really probe into what's going on. I'd look for someone who's more of an analyst type who'll want to probe deep into childhood experiences etc., rather than a more here-and-now oriented CBT type of therapist, for this kind of thing.

Whether you end up transitioning or not, you'll make a far better decision if you understand *why* you want to do it.

posts.name: Anonymous

Go and see a good therapist.

And read some good self-help books. Some good starting points:
- 12 Rules For Life by Jordan Peterson
- The Subtle Art of Not Giving A Fuck by Mark Manson
- if you're a Star Wars fan by any chance, get your hands on a copy of The Journey of Luke Skywalker by Steven Galipeau. It's not a self-help book as such, but it honestly changed my life.

Above all, stop inventing grand narratives about yourself. Lying –whether it's to yourself or others –won't do you any good. Instead, learn to really listen to yourself, and try to figure out who you truly are.

>>29134996
No e2 spiking SHBG never messes with feminization, because the free E2 rises proportionally with SHBG, with the free E2 always being higher.

High levels can effect feminization though, but that's because higher levels cause more downregulation of ERa and upregulation of ERb. Both bad for feminization.

But they dont really inhibit it totally, and even then it's not awful awful, it's just not optimal.

I dont really know what you mean by the DHT/T thing, aside from that some people can still have higher levels of DHT with suppressed T. But in those situations a higher SHBG is a good thing, and can be used as a moderate defense against higher than wanted T/DHT and other androgens. I honestly cant think of a situation SHBG becomes a bad things for us, aside from synthetic estrogens, and possibly certain doses of oral estradiol.

Yes the ERa/Erb is interesting. Aside from that, high doses to a point give more visceral fat patterning, and possibly stunted breast growth. But wont ever stunt a transition exactly. I've ran 3500pg/ml levels for several years as well as normal levels, and it's just not as awful as so people make out, but it'd be better to maintain good levels for sure.

I transitioned at 18ish. Detransitioned at 27 due to legal problems. Pre op in man prison, bad juju. Got mastectomy, but due to orchi wasn't making T. Lack of boobs is nice, I never cared about those. Loss of sensation to the nips makes me v sad.

After a couple years out and off any HRT, decided to try T because of general fatigue/moodiness. I've regained about 20lbs of muscle, and have a bit more energy in general. I have less facial hair than I did as a teen. Orgasms are much less intense, but more wet. I still look relatively young, probably due to lack of typical masculine features for a 30yo man. I preferred being svelte and hairless, but honestly E made my mood super erratic. Made it really hard to keep a job, relationship, or any kind of stability. I don't consider myself fully detransitioned, more of a happy medium. My T levels and masculine features are pretty minimal, but I've got some vitality and libido benefits. Miss the intense orgasms and physical build E gave me.

>>29134208
Thai hon is here to tell you that you shouldn't worry about clots too much :v I had DVT in my right leg and varicose in both feet prior to trooning. We treated it with warfarin, but after that I was out on 81mg of aspirin at bedtime daily. It's a standard rec for people at risk of heart attack, clots, and whatnot. I've been on it for 4y, ~2.5 of which I've been on HRT (pills and injections, I'm on pills again), no signs of DVT recurring or anything like that.
You should be careful while using bloodthinners if you have a history of intestinal bleeding, but if it's nothing chronic (which is actually rare), don't worry too much. The way you spot intestinal bleeding is by checking the colour of your stool, if you bleed on the inside, it'll turn black, not just dark brown, but black and tarry. That said, intestinal ulcers that usually are the cause of non-chronic types of bleeding aren't that hard to treat, it takes less than a month, and after that it's mostly about maintaining a decent diet.

>>29130322
Catmen are most certainly the future.

To be a catboy/girl, is less about aestheticizing the physical signifiers of a cat, and more so about the invocation of behavioral and archetypical norms surrounding felines. That is to say, while the twinkish, youthful physical appearance, often bordering on androgyny, is a commonality of the catboy aesthetic, I believe it arises more from the "boy" than the "cat." A catboy is considered a cat in the sense that they adopt associations with cats that people find attractive. i.e, to be a catboy is to be, lithe, agile, graceful, playful, and in extreme cases, invoke the anachronistic antics of cats, interpreted through the lens of human eccentricity.

However, there is nothing mutually exclusive about being a man, or even masculine, that clashes with being a cat. Instead of imagining a boy who acts like a playful and lovey kitten, imagen a man who is, sly, standoffish, easy come easy go, and uncomfortable with expressing attraction despite being really loving deep down. Instead of a kitten, think of the wily magic cat from folklore, or the grouchy but loveable family house pet.

To better elucidate what I mean here, consider the divide between what we consider a "catgirl" and a "catwoman." A catgirl is a cutesy, anime-inspired pop astetic, whereas a catwoman is more associated with femdom bdsm.

I think that the last few generations have shown a worrying trend of fetishizing youth to an unhealthy degree, and while there is undoubtedly beauty in youth, learning to reconcile ones mature body with one's ascetic preferences is key to a happy and long life. Many, of what we would call "boomerhons" are off putting in large part because they invoke fashion choices they simply cannot pull off. An 18 year old e-girl looks pretty in thigh high socks and a miniskirt, but a 40 year old woman does not, cis or trans.

Embrace mature beauty, embrace catmen!

The soft skills that will help a person pass are:
1) Basic makeup skills to hide beardshadow and to a no-makep-makeup or a minimal makeup look (works better for passing that louder makeup looks because it acts on people subconsciously).
2) Dress age, region and social class appropriately for a woman of your age, in your social circles.
3) Padded bras always help.
4) Take proper care of your hair. Shampoo only the roots, condition from above the roots to the ends with LOTS of conditioner and leave it on for 5 mins. If you can, blow dry your hair on low heat to minimize friziness. Get a dry shampoo for days you don't wash your hair. Don't wash your hair more than 2-3x a week.
5) Voice train.

Those should be enough to get you passing to cis normies as long as you have a decentish starting place.

posts.com:
>>29134231
What colour of corrector you needs depends on the undertone of your beard shadow and the colour of your skin. If you have green tinged beard shadow you need a pink-to-red palate corrector, if your beard shadow is blueish, you need dark-peach-to-light-peach palate. The lighter your skin, the lighter the corrector needs to be. I'm pale and have green tinged shadow so I use a medium pink colour corrector (not the bright pink kind used under the eyes).

The process for getting CC to work best:
1) Apply a good makeup primer. I use ELF's poreless putty primer. Wait a couple of mins, then:
2) Apply some colour corrector to a flat surface and work into the tips of the bristles of a dense, stiff bristled brush and stipple it onto the beard shadow areas with a repeated tapping motion. You are aiming to drive the colour corrector INTO the skin where the shadow is, not just on top of it. Use a little bit at a time! You shouldn't be using so much that you look super orange. I use LA Girl's colour corrector line. I think it gives much better results than the palate colour correctors usually recommended for this.
3) Apply a good quality bb corrector using your fingers to spread it over your face. This will give a smoother texture than using a beauty blender or brush. I use Missha BB Cream in shade #21. I think it gives the most coverage relative to how much makeup you look like you're wearing.

>>29096221
I love the number 5 because it's so closely linked to us. 5 limbs, 5 digits. There are 5 classical elements in Greek, Indian, and Chinese mythology (the 5th gets often shortened to 4 for the Greeks, though). Romans have a numeral dedicated to 5, while most other numbers require multiple digits. Chinese abacus's group numbers by 5 as well. Universally most methods of counting are the same up to the number 5 in a majority of cultures

In addition, there are 5 platonic solids in the 3rd dimension, 6 in the 4th dimension, and then every dimension afterwards only can contain 3. The 1st 4-dimensional platonic solid is coincidentally known as the 5-cell, and when viewed orthographically, it becomes a pentagram!

For a fun lesson in neurology, our brains stop at 4 as the largest grouping we can instantly recognize (known as the Parallel Individuation System). Any number 5 or larger and we switch to a different system in our brain to estimate quantities

posts.name: bagel

>>29110294
if you have trouble with eye contact, look at people's noses or brows instead. they won't be able to tell. make sure you blink though
if you want to not seem so socially awkward (this is a bit of a weird one) keep lists of people's interests and talk to them about them, let them do most of the talking. try to only use one or two per conversation or they might catch on, although if they do and they're understanding it might be better
it really depends mostly on what the specifics of your autism are, since it's an incredibly broad spectrum
